DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
19th February 2020 

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Production of favipiravir, first antiviral drug approved by Chinese authorities to treat nCoV, is reportedly well in progress and is expected to hit the market later in February with the first batch estimated to reach 100,000 pills; GT citing reports. (Global Times)

China's EU ambassador said coronavirus epidemic on China's economy is limited, short term and manageable. Investors need not to worry as the government has sufficient resources to boost the economy. (Newswires)

WHO Chief Tedros said that at present there are 92 cases outside of China of human-to-human coronavirus spread. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

China's President Xi said that China is still able to meet the 2020 economic targets, in-spite of the impact of the coronavirus, State Media. (Newswires)

China is to encourage firms to boost their imports of medical supplies and agricultural goods, according to the Commerce Ministry. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that the US cannot and will not become a difficult place to deal with, regarding foreign purchases of products, that Co's are forced to leave to remain competitive. Noted that he wants China to purchase our jet engines. (Newswires)

US State Department said Chinese state-run media operating in the US will need to register US-based employees and operations, citing propaganda for the new registration rules. (Newswires)

US Judge has dismissed the Huawei lawsuit against the US which alleged that the US improperly limited its US business. according to the court ruling. (Newswires)

UK/EU

EU nations are readying to toughen conditions they will attach to any FTA with the UK; the latest version of the mandate has responded to some EU concerns that it did not go far enough in requiring UK to stick to EU regulations even as it evolves. The revised document also makes clear that any agreement should uphold EU fishermen’s current rights in the UK [This is a key sticking point in talks]. (FT)

EZ Finance Minister, including German Finance Minister Scholz, have adopted a recommendation for a fiscal boost in the event of a downturn. (Newswires)

ECB's Panetta (Neutral) said that any Euro area expansion must be accompanied by measures to deepen it in a political and economic sense. (Newswires)

FX

South Africa's Eskom says while no loadshedding is expected at the moment, there is potential for loadshedding tomorrow. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Turkish Presidency spokesman said deployment of troops to Syria's Idlib will continue and attacks from Assad's forces will see retaliation in kind. (Newswires)

Libya's Tripoli port is reportedly coming under intense artilery bombardment from LNA forces for around 30-minutes, with shells landing near densely populated areas of the old city and major oil Co. HQ's - UNCONFIRMED twitter reports. (Twitter)

COMMODITIES

Russian Kremlin says that Energy Minister Novak is still continuing talks with OPEC+ partners regarding a future deal. Russian Deputy Energy Minister Sorokin said that the OPEC+ meeting will occur as planned on March 6th in Vienna. (Newswires)

Libya Oil Output falls to 123.5k BPD, according to NOC - down from Monday's 135.75k BPD. Libya NOC said fuel tankers are being evacuated from ports after shelling near IPG tanker. UN Libya Envoy has received conditions from Eastern tribesman for lifting the oil blockade, these must be addressed within UN dialogue (Newswires)

US total shale regions oil productions in March seen +17k BPD to 9.174mln BPD, EIA said. (Newswires)

US Special Envoy to Venezuela Abrams says US will hold further conversations with Spanish officials regarding Venezuela oil, where he would expect some of Repsol's (REP SM) operations will have to change in the region. (Newswires)

US 

Fed's Kaplan (Voter) said that US interest rate setting is roughly appropriate, sees no change through the year; coronavirus poses downside risk, and they are assessing the implications for US growth. Adds, open to other options for limiting balance sheet growth. (Newswires)

Democratic Presidential Candidate Bloomberg has qualified for the Nevada debate this Wednesday after reaching 19% support in new NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll, according to a Bloomberg News journalist on Twitter. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 7 TICKS HIGHER AT 131-06+: The Treasury curve bull-flattened as Apple's revenue warning on Monday spooked risk. The 2s10s curve narrowed to a 14-handle, the lowest since November 2019; yields on 30s briefly fell sub-2.00%, while yields on 10s fell slightly below 1.54%. Traders also cited a weak ZEW report out of Germany in the morning (first post-Coronavirus survey).

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.29% at 3370, NDX +0.06% at 9630, DJI -0.56% at 29,232. Semiconductors took a hit from a Monday report that the Trump administration is weighing new trade restrictions on China that would limit the use of American chip-making equipment, as it seeks to cut off Chinese access to key semiconductor technology. Elsewhere, Samsung (SSNLF, 005930 KS) reportedly won a 5-nm chip manufacturing deal with Qualcomm (QCOM) for 5G X60 modem chip, according to source reports. AMD (AMD) traded higher today with desks citing high call activity. Tesla (TSLA) rose over 6% as bear Adam Jonas of Morgan Stanley increased his bull case for the automaker to USD 1200/shr (prev. USD 650, Friday’s close USD 800), the analyst also increased his base case to USD 500/shr from USD 360, while reiterating his underweight stance. Bernstein also increased its PT to USD 730 from USD 325, noting TSLA “is the ultimate possibility stock” and it could be argued it is “not unprecedentedly expensive”. Kroger (KR) and Biogen (BIIB) were bid as Berkshire Hathaway disclosed the two new companies as new additions in its 13-F. Conagra Brands (CAG) were hit after it cut its outlook after poor Q3 performance. Franklin Resources (BEN) performed well on the announcement it is to acquire its rival Legg Mason (LM) for USD 50/shr (Friday closing price: USD 40.72), in fitting with WSJ source reports this morning. BEN will assume USD 2bln of LM’s outstanding debt and the deal will see BEN as one of the largest independent, specialised global investment managers with a combined USD 1.5trln in AUM.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 18th February 2020: Stocks pare back sharp Apple-related losses, though gold still shines
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries up, dollar up, crude mixed.
  • REAR VIEW: AAPL revenue warning; Empire manufacturing big beat; Canada factory numbers miss; corona deaths fall in China; WMT misses estimates; dovish RBA minutes; EU to toughen Brexit negotiating stance.
  • UPCOMING: CBRT Monetary Policy Decision, FOMC Minutes (Jan), US Democratic Debate, Australian Wage Price Index, Swedish CPIF, UK Inflation, Canadian CPI, US PPI, Housing Starts, Building Permits.

* MARKET WRAP: Markets traded risk-off overnight after Apple (AAPL) Monday warned it might not meet revenue guidance due to the impact of coronavirus on Chinese demand, slow normalisation of working conditions, as well as iPhone production constraints. Major Asian equity bourses were in the red, as were European indices as US players returned after the President's Day holiday, while the Treasury curve had bull-flattened, and major crude benchmarks had shed over a buck; haven FX was more tempered, though gold was firmer (perhaps the notable outperformer of the day, topping USD 1,600, and eyeing January high around 1,611). The NY Fed manufacturing survey was much better than expected, which did help add some positivity to sentiment, though is ultimately not very representative of the US manufacturing sector; Canada manufacturing data, by contrast, was grim. In later trade, the Nasdaq 100 turned positive (where AAPL holds a 12% weighting), perhaps suggesting that investors are already beginning to look beyond the AAPL story; crude also pared back sharp losses to end the session approximately flat.

* APPLE (AAPL): The technology giant Monday announced it was no longer expecting to meet revenue guidance for the March quarter as a result of the coronavirus, which has impacted Chinese demand and disrupted supply chains. Desks are mixed in their views of the implications of the news: Piper Sandler & Baird suggested buying on weakness, JPMorgan urges long-term shareholders to look past the “temporary headwinds”, and Citi highlighted that demand outside of China was still strong and the outlook is promising with the upcoming 5G cycle, and thus maintained its buy rating. Elsewhere, Wedbush said this news was unexpected and clearly worse than feared given the timing of the release. Barclays cut its PT to USD 297 from USD 304, although noted the announcement was not unexpected, but highlighted a risk the tech giant is too exposed to China. Whereas, Morgan Stanley adjusted its shorter-term expectations, but its FY expectations remain unchanged. The story also weighed on Apple suppliers (SWKS, QCOM, MCHP, MU), and many semiconductors traded in the red, including Intel (INTC), which resulted in the Dow underperforming.

* US EMPIRE MANUFACTURING: It was an upside surprise for the Empire Manufacturing Survey, printing 12.9 (against an expected 5.00 and a prior 4.8), the highest since May 2019, and as BMO notes, the biggest beat when compared to the survey forecast since March 2018. "Elements of the details were quite solid, particularly new orders (strongest since Sep 2017) and shipments (highest since Nov 2018)," BMO writes, though says that the sustainability of these developments will be a key question in calibrating any factory resilience in Q1; however, all being equal, this should help keep the FOMC on hold for a bit longer and moderate near-term cut calls, the bank writes.

* FED MINUTES PREVIEW: The FOMC meeting minutes are unlikely to reveal much by way of new information, and will likely reiterate the points made within the post-meeting statement, post-meeting press conference with Chair Powell, as well as Powell’s views expressed in his recent dual-testimonies to lawmakers. The Fed is monitoring the impact of the coronavirus, and there will be a great deal of attention on any commentary around this theme, given tech-giant Apple recently cut guidance due to the outbreak; the Fed is likely to reiterate that it would need a substantial shift from its baseline for it to tweak policy settings. Additionally, traders will be eyeing any commentary that gives insights into the course for the Fed’s repo operations, as well as any commentary on the upcoming policy review. Minutes will be released at 1900 GMT/1400 ET on 19th February 2020. To download the report, please click here

* CANADA MANUFACTURING SALES: It was another grim data report from Canada, with manufacturing sales falling by 0.7% M/M against expectations of a 0.5% rise; the prior was also unrevised. Canadian bank RBC notes that manufacturing continues to be dragged on by temporary factors, but even so, underlying trends have been soft. "The outlook is being clouded once again by concerns about the impact on global industrial chains from the novel coronavirus outbreak and, in Canada, another round of disruptions to rail transportation via the ongoing blockade of main rail lines, particularly in eastern Canada," RBC writes, "we continue to expect overall Canadian economic growth will remain on the soft side in early 2020 after little or no growth in the last quarter of 2019."

* RBA MINUTES: There wasn't anything particularly new revealed in the RBA's recent meeting minutes. The Board mulled lowering the cash rate due to the only gradual progress towards the Bank's inflation and unemployment goals, though the Board recognised that the incremental benefits of further interest rate reductions needed to be weighed against the risks associated with very low interest rates, concluding that rates should be held steady, and that it was reasonable to expect an extended period of low interest rates to reach full employment and achieve the inflation target. It also reiterated that it would continue monitoring developments including in the labour market, and was prepared to ease policy if needed to support sustainable growth in the economy, full employment and the achievement of the inflation target over time. RBC's analysts said it was clear that the central bank's easing bias was firmly intact, though it thinks the hurdle to cut rates further has lifted amid a central bank that currently sees greater costs from further cuts than benefits.

* WTI (J0) SETTLED USD 0.03 LOWER AT USD 52.29/BBL; BRENT SETTLED USD 0.08 HIGHER AT USD 57.75/BBL. Crude benchmarks are lower, having pared back a deeper loss, with desks once again examining the demand impact of the coronavirus; concerns have been amplified after tech giant Apple's warnings Monday. Additionally, desks were noting the restart of production in the Saudi/Kuwait neutral zone (500k BPD has been shuttered since 2015) was not helping. UBS notes, however, that Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have consistently been among the most supportive of OPEC+ production cuts, and the bank expects any ramp-up in production from the neutral zone to be managed in accordance with commitments to the supply curb agreement. The downside also coincided with familiar remarks from Russia, that talks are ongoing regarding their position on the OPEC+ deal, whilst noting the March 6th OPEC+ meeting will go ahead as planned. WTI and Brent found lows at 50.88 and 60.93, respectively. Once lows were hit, the benchmarks saw a turnaround amid comments from Iran’s Energy Minister Zanganeh who noted that some oil projects have come to a halt due to a lack of funding. This week’s inventory expectations (bbls): Crude +3.8mln, Distillates -1.7mln, Gasoline +0.5mln.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 7 TICKS HIGHER AT 131-06+: The Treasury curve bull-flattened as Apple's revenue warning on Monday spooked risk. The 2s10s curve narrowed to a 14-handle, the lowest since November 2019; yields on 30s briefly fell sub-2.00%, while yields on 10s fell slightly below 1.54%. Traders also cited a weak ZEW report out of Germany in the morning (first post-Coronavirus survey).

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.29% at 3370, NDX +0.06% at 9630, DJI -0.56% at 29,232. Sectors: Financials -0.88%, Energy -0.83%, Industrials -0.56%, Consumer staples -0.4%, Health Care -0.37%. Tech -0.35%, Materials -0.23%, Real Estate -0.15%, Consumer Disc. +0.08%, Communication +0.4%, Utilities +0.8%

* EARNINGS: Walmart (WMT) saw choppy trade in wake of its earnings, initially the retail giant traded in the red following EPS & revenue misses, whilst also same store sales also disappointed. However, the weakness was due to the protests in Chile and as well as a legal matter affecting Sam’s club. On the coronavirus, WMT stated it will continue to monitor the outlook, but it is not lowering its sales forecast this year as a result of nCoV at this time. Leidos (LDOS) and Advanced Auto Parts (AAP) were firmer following earnings, whereas Vulcan Materials (VMC), and Allegion (ALLE) were hit.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Semiconductors took a hit from a Monday report that the Trump administration is weighing new trade restrictions on China that would limit the use of American chip-making equipment, as it seeks to cut off Chinese access to key semiconductor technology. Elsewhere, Samsung (SSNLF, 005930 KS) reportedly won a 5-nm chip manufacturing deal with Qualcomm (QCOM) for 5G X60 modem chip, according to source reports. AMD (AMD) traded higher today with desks citing high call activity. Tesla (TSLA) rose over 6% as bear Adam Jonas of Morgan Stanley increased his bull case for the automaker to USD 1200/shr (prev. USD 650, Friday’s close USD 800), the analyst also increased his base case to USD 500/shr from USD 360, while reiterating his underweight stance. Bernstein also increased its PT to USD 730 from USD 325, noting TSLA “is the ultimate possibility stock” and it could be argued it is “not unprecedentedly expensive”. Kroger (KR) and Biogen (BIIB) were bid as Berkshire Hathaway disclosed the two new companies as new additions in its 13-F. Conagra Brands (CAG) were hit after it cut its outlook after poor Q3 performance. Franklin Resources (BEN) performed well on the announcement it is to acquire its rival Legg Mason (LM) for USD 50/shr (Friday closing price: USD 40.72), in fitting with WSJ source reports this morning. BEN will assume USD 2bln of LM’s outstanding debt and the deal will see BEN as one of the largest independent, specialised global investment managers with a combined USD 1.5trln in AUM.

* FX WRAP: The Dollar continues its march upwards, with weak German ZEW data adding to the haven-bid in early trade; EUR hit fresh multi-year lows sub-1.07 as the slide continues; both the offshore and onshore yuans are trading back above 7.00 - desks have cited a report which suggests watching the correlation between oil and the yuan for clues about how the coronavirus fears are playing out, with the theory that if virus fears ease, China would pare back stimulus, lending to yuan upside, while crude would likely bounce on hopes of a demand recovery. Gold managed to bust through 1,600, just short of YTD highs, after a risk-off feel to trade, although haven FX's gains were more modest. Unsurprisingly, risk-sensitive FX (AUD, NZD, SEK) were lower, with the AUD also weighed by dovish RBA minutes. EMFX also took its cue from the broader risk tone, trading lower. GBP is flat, supported by EUR weakness and a decent labour market headline, though the internals left much to be desired, while desks are also noting Brexit risk is rising amid contentious negotiations with the EU. CAD felt the combo of USD strength and a grim factory report.

* USD, EUR: The Dollar index continued its march higher amid risk-off trading conditions. SocGen's strategists noted that option traders have thrown in the towel following the slide in EURUSD spot, with EUR puts now trading at a premium over calls from 1-week to 6-months out. SocGen also notes that the correlation of 0.86 between spot and risk-reversals is the highest since mid-November, a level which in the past typically has been followed by reversals in spot. The bank adds, however, that risk-reversals and oversold technicals (the RSI at 24) is a red flag, and a mean-reverting bounce could be imminent, though it still does not compel the bank to abandon its bearish view, noting that although recent moves have been sizeable, a EURUSD fall sub-1.08 towards 1.0735 remains eminently possible until the full scale of the corona-led slowdown in China becomes clear.

* GBP: UK jobs data saw a decent headline, though wage growth metrics disappointed. Traders continued to cite Brexit risk; Brexit negotiator Frost Monday pushed-back on EU demands for a 'level playing field', and threatened to walk away from negotiations if the EU did not drop its demand for the UK to follow its rules post-Brexit. Frost's punchy remarks followed comments made by the French foreign minister over the weekend, who said the UK and EU would 'rip each other apart' in trade negotiations – a reminder of that theme was provided in late trade, with reports suggesting that EU nations were readying tougher conditions to attach to any FTA with the UK. GBP drifted sub-1.30 against the USD, and almost fell to 0.8275 against the EUR, though ultimately the EUR's weakness helped the GBP recover, while the 1.30 figure has been retained against the buck.

* AUD: The Aussie traded lower after minute revealed that the RBA had mulled rate cuts at its recent policy meeting, though concerns about household borrowing persuaded the central bank to stand pat. Fragile risk sentiment was also a factor after Apple's China warning, which was also echoed in the RBA's minutes, which said the outbreak would dampen exports through H1 2020.

* KRW: After the Philippine and Thai central banks cut rates earlier in the month, there may be signs that South Korea will follow. Overnight, South Korea declared an economic emergency, and President Moon said the government must make every effort to protect the economy; traders interpreted Moon's remarks as a call on the BOK to ease policy to cushion against the fallout of the virus, like other regional counterparts.

Daily FX Wrap: Euro enters race to the base, but Kiwi now the major laggard
content:
USD

After another relatively brief interlude, fresh gains for the broad Dollar pushed the DXY further above 99.000 to a new ytd high of 99.480 and closer to the 2019 pinnacle at 99.667. A considerable Empire State headline beat gave the Greenback a lift, but in truth the latest leg up was forged at the expense of others in part, if not large extent.

NZD/AUD 

Under the cosh all day, but in company earlier, Kiwi losses have now accumulated towards last Tuesday’s 2020 base, at 0.6384 vs 0.6378 and irrespective of sharp declines in GDT dairy prices. In fact, Nzd/Usd is now off worst levels even though Aud/Nzd remains elevated above 1.0450 and the Aussie is holding up better within a 0.6715-0.6674 range against its US counterpart after RBA minutes underlining why deeper rate cuts could be more problematic than prescriptive if lower borrowing costs entice higher levels of credit.

SCANDI 

The Kronas have both pared some losses on the back of a partial recovery in broad risk sentiment that has filtered through to oil prices, but Eur/Sek is still hovering near highs posted after Swedish jobs data showing a bigger than forecast rebound in the sa unemployment rate and an even more pronounced spike in the nsa measure, circa 10.5600 vs Eur/Nok around the middle of 10.0220-10.1100 parameters.

CHF/EUR/CAD 

Some respite for the Franc, Euro and Loonie in wake of a broad Buck fade, but Usd/Chf is still comfortably above 0.9800 and Eur/Chf has only managed a tame bounce from close to 1.0600 lows in line with a lame revival in Eur/Usd from 1.0785 or so back above 1.0800. To recap, a pretty downbeat ZEW survey added more evidence to the downside tilt to the German/Eurozone economy, and did preface all Eurogroup members backing a recommendation to provide fiscal stimulus if the slowdown intensifies, but to what degree and how bad things need to become is unknown. Similarly, Usd/Cad soaked up offers at 1.3270 before consolidating when Canadian manufacturing sales fell far short of expectations, but the pair has pared back towards 1.3250 ahead of Wednesday’s more pertinent CPI release.

GBP/JPY/XAU

Sterling has staged an impressive or even improbable comeback from early EU session lows, of sub-1.3000 in Cable and close to 0.8350 on the Eur/Gbp cross, but the Pound ran into resistance ahead of 1.3050 and 0.8277 respectively (latter representing the 2019 low). The initial catalyst appeared to be chart based as Cable held in at a key DMA/Fib convergence point, but then encouraging UK jobs data also helped and the Gbp is holding up well in the face of more extracts from a draft EU document underlining level playing field criteria within a revised trade negotiating mandate. Elsewhere, the Yen is keeping its head above 110.00 against the backdrop of risk-off positioning, but lagging Gold as a safe-haven as Usd/Xau tests the psychological Usd1600/oz mark.

EM

The aforementioned Dollar wane from best levels has afforded some solace to regional currencies, but the mood remains bearish on renewed risk aversion over the impact rather than direct effect of China’s deadly virus that does appear to be topping out, thankfully. Usd/Cnh has nudged back over 7.0000 as a result, while Usd/Rub has revisited 64.0000+ and Usd/Try popped above 6.0700 amidst ongoing geopolitical strains between Turkey and Russia in Syria and Russia-Ukraine separately. However, Usd/Zar has retreated towards 15.0000 after the SARB highlighted increased sovereign risk as a reason for higher rates despite lower inflation expectations, and on that note the Lira is eyeing the CBRT tomorrow to find out if the benchmark raised are reduced again (consensus -50 bp) in the face of firmer than forecast CPI prints in the run up.

subject: US equities pare pre-market losses, but still open red after Apple says it will miss guidance; TSLA +6% following PT upgrades from MS and Bernstein
content:
Gainers

  • Leidos (LDOS) +10% after its earnings report
  • Advanced Auto Parts (AAP) +8.5% following an EPS beat
  • Franklin Resources (BEN) +8% after it announced it is to acquire Legg Mason (LM) (+24%) for USD 50/shr
  • Kroger (KR) +8% once Berkshire Hathaway disclosed a stake in the co.

Losers

  • Conagra Brands (CAG) -7.4% as it revised its FY outlook due to poor performance in Q3
  • Allegion (ALLE) -4.4% following poor revenue guidance and an EPS miss
  • KLA corp (KLAC) -4% as US President Trump’s administration is considering restrictions on China that would limit use of US chip-making equipment.
analysis_details: US indices opened lower across the board following Apple’s (AAPL) announcement it no longer expects to meet its revenue guidance provided for the March quarter as it is experiencing a slower return to conditions than expected which has resulted in worldwide iPhone supply being temporarily constrained, while demand in China is restricted. However, US equity futures have begun to pare back some of the losses following the open, although Apple (AAPL) trade with losses of ~2% and has seen the Technology sector -0.6%, paring back from around 0.8% at the open. The tech sector also getting hit by semiconductors, following reports the Trump administration is considering new trade restrictions that would limit US chip-making equipment. Energy also underperforming on lower oil prices amid general risk sentiment, although WTI and Brent have bounced off lows following the energy cash open and amid comments from Iran that a lack of funding has resulted in a pause of operations. Utilities are among outperformers given the defensive nature of the sector, as is Real Estate and Consumer Staples. Whereas Consumer Discretionary performs well following earnings from Advanced Auto Parts (AAP).

subject: PREVIEW: FOMC meeting minutes (Jan 2020) will be released at 1900 GMT/1400 ET on 19th February 2020
content:
• The FOMC meeting minutes are unlikely to reveal much by way of new information, and will likely reiterate the points made within the post-meeting statement, post-meeting press conference with Chair Powell, as well as Powell’s views expressed in his recent dual-testimonies to lawmakers. The Fed is monitoring the impact of the coronavirus, and there will be a great deal of attention on any commentary around this theme, given tech-giant Apple recently cut guidance due to the outbreak; the Fed is likely to reiterate that it would need a substantial shift from its baseline for it to tweak policy settings. Additionally, traders will be eyeing any commentary that gives insights into the course for the Fed’s repo operations, as well as any commentary on the upcoming policy review. Minutes will be released at 1900 GMT/1400 ET on 19th February 2020. To download the report, please click here

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 18th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Apple (AAPL) announced it does not expect to meet its revenue guidance provided for the March quarter
  • Tesla (TSLA) had its PT increased to USD 500 at Morgan Stanley, who also increased its bull case target to USD 1200, while Bernstein also increased its PT on the automaker to USD 730 from USD 325
  • Franklin Resources (BEN) is to acquire its rival Legg Mason (LM) for USD 50/shr

18th February 2020

  • Of note for Semiconductors (SOX, QCOM, INTC), US President Trump's administration is reportedly weighing new trade restrictions on China that would limit the use of American chip-making equipment, as it seeks to cut off Chinese access to key semiconductor technology, according to people familiar with the matter. Note, on Friday, The Hill reported GOP Senator Rick Scott proposed a bill to restrict US sales to Huawei, cutting the minimum requirement of US made parts from 25% to 10% in its products.
  • Of note for Airlines/Boeing (BA, AAL, LUV, DAL, UAL), US President Trump’s Administration said it would increase tariffs on EU aircrafts from March 18th on planes from France, Germany, Spain, and the UK, which will be subject to 15% tariffs, up from the prior 10% that took effect in October. USTR noted that it remains open to a negotiated settlement. Prior duties will remain on certain other European products such as Scotch and French wine at 25%, according to WSJ.
  • This week’s Barron’s articles highlight that natgas prices fell beneath USD 2/MMBtu on January 21st, a price which most producers in the US cannot make money from drilling new wells. Barron’s suggested avoiding natgas stocks, apart from Cabot Oil & Gas (COG) and Cheniere Energy (LNG). Elsewhere, the author highlighted the risk that Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL) are facing regulatory risks, citing comments from Facebook (FB) CFO Wehner noting GDPR and CCPA will impact its ability to use its signals from user activity on third party websites and services to deliver relevant and effective ads to its users. Of note for Bed Bath and Beyond (BBBY), Barron’s wrote “pain and patience are in store for Bed Bath & Beyond shareholders—despite nearly a year of activist prodding”. The publication also spoke to investors, who forecast a USD ~900mln opportunity in aggregate if its non-core brands are sold, with hopes that deals will be announced shortly. Barron’s also noted that Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) “busted bid” for eBay (EBAY) is an opening for investors, noting the interest in EBAY indicates that the model in exchange businesses may soon evolve. For Boston Beer (SAM), Barron’s highlighted a new Credit Suisse report which predicted hard seltzer sales will double this year and see 8-10% of beer sales by 2023, which Barron’s note is excellent news for SAM.

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) announced it does not expect to meet its revenue guidance provided for the March quarter due to demand within China has been effected by coronavirus, which has resulted in store closures, reduced operating hours and lower footfall, and iPhone supply was being temporarily constrained. Elsewhere, DigiTimes reports that the new iPad Pro is due for release in March. Many banks have held a range of opinions on Apple today: Piper Sandler suggests buying the dip, JP Morgan urges long-term shareholders to look past the “temporary headwinds”, and Citi highlights that demand outside of China is still strong and the outlook is promising with the release of 5G, thus Citi are maintaining its buy rating. Elsewhere, Wedbush said this news was unexpected and clearly worse than feared given the timing of the release. Barclays cut its PT to USD 297 from USD 304, although noted the announcement was not unexpected, but highlighted a risk the tech giant is too exposed to China. Whereas, Morgan Stanley adjusted its shorter-term expectations, but its FY expectations remain unchanged.
  • Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) told the FAA that it does not believe it has to separate the or move wiring bundles on the 737 MAX, which regulators warned could short circuit with “catastrophic consequences”, according to people familiar with the matter.
  • JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) (Financials/Diversified Banks) named Viswas Raghavan and James Casey as the new global co-heads of investment banking amid its leadership share up, according to sources, who note the bank created an executive committee of eighteen global Chairs under Carlos Hernandez.
  • Visa Inc. (V) (Information Technology/IT Services) and Accor announced a partnership to bring payment experiences to Accor’s Live Limitless members.
  • Walmart Inc (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 1.38 (exp. 1.44), Revenue 141.7bln (exp. 142.52bln); US Q4 comp sales +1.9% (exp. +2.4%), total comp sales +1.8% (exp. 2.2%). Net sales 140.61bln (prev. 137.74bln). FY20 EPS 5.00-5.15 (exp. 5.22). Quarterly GAAP & adj. EPS lowered by circa USD 0.05 due to disruptions in Chile as well as a legal matter affecting Sam's Club. The retailer also highlighted that weakness was also driven by softness in toys and apparel over December (HAS, MAT). The retailer notes Walmex, China and Flipkart had a solid quarter. Of note, the hypermarket said it was not lowering its sales forecast this year due to coronavirus, but was continuing to monitor the outlook.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc Class A (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) spokesman announced that its Cloud unit will be eliminating a small number of jobs.
  • Gilead Sciences (GILD) (Health Care/Biotechnology) HIV treatment, remdesivir, which is being tested for treatment of the coronavirus is reportedly going slower than planned amid struggles to recruit qualified patients, according to WSJ.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) bear Adam Jonas of Morgan Stanley, increased his bull case for the automaker to USD 1200/shr (prev. USD 650, Friday’s close USD 800), the analyst also increased his base case to USD 500/shr from USD 360, while reiterating his underweight stance. Bernstein also increased its PT to USD 730 from USD 325, noting TSLA “is the ultimate possibility stock” and it could be argued it is “not unprecedentedly expensive”. Elsewhere, reports over the bank holiday stated two Tesla drivers believed the autopilot saved their life by breaking faster than they could have reacted in response to a fallen tree as a result of Storm Dennis in the UK.

S&P 500

  • Advance Auto Parts (AAP) (Consumer Discretionary/Automotive Retail) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 1.64 (exp. 1.35), Revenue 2.1bln (exp. 2.12bln). FY20 Revenue view 9.88-10.1bln (exp. 9.93bln).
  • Air Lease (AL) (Industrials/Trading Companies & Distributors) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 1.42 (Adj. EPS 1.92) (exp. 1.38), revenue 0.55bln (exp. 0.535bln)
  • Allegion (ALLE) (Industrials/Building Products) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 1.28 (exp. 1.29), Revenue 0.72bln (exp. 0.73bln). FY EPS view 5.10-5.20 (exp. 5.32), FY Revenue growth view +3-4%.
  • Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) (Health Care/Health Care Distributors) announced updated results from its Phase 3 CheckMate-214 study evaluating Opdivo in combination with Yervoy vs sunitinib, noting Opdivo plus Yervoy was consistent with prior findings and no new safety signals or drug related deaths occurred with extended follow up. The five-year follow up results saw Opdivo continue to demonstrate overall survival benefit with 26% of patients alive compared to 18% of patients treated with everolimus.
  • Conagra Brands (CAG) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) revised its FY20 outlook due to poor Q3 performance. Organic net sales growth expected 0-0.5%, adj. operating margin expected between 15.8-16.2%, and adj. diluted EPS from cont. ops between USD 2.00-2.07.
  • CVS Health (CVS) (Health Care/Health Care Services) announced the DoJ served the company with a DEA administrative subpoena which is looking for documents related to practices with respect to opioids and other controlled substances at the pharmacy locations.
  • DuPont de Nemours Inc (DD) (Materials/Specialty Chemicals) CEO Doyle and CFO Desmond are to leave the company effective immediately, where Edward Breen, current executive chairman is to be CEO and Lori Koch, VP of investor relations, is to be CFO. The leadership change was conducted to accelerate operation performance improvement and to use Breen’s management expertise.
  • Ecolab Inc. (ECL) (Materials/Specialty Chemicals) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. diluted EPS 1.66 (exp. 1.69), Revenue 3.82bln (exp. 3.88bln). FY20 Adj. EPS view 6.33-6.53 (exp. 5.45).
  • Expeditors (EXPD) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.79 (exp. 0.87), Revenue 2.0bln (exp. 2.15bln). Large uncertainty remains around return of production at its China factories, and that factory delays will have a significant impact on freight volumes moved in Q1.
  • Flowserve Corporation (FLS) (Industrials/Industrial Machinery) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.66 (exp. 0.65), revenue 1.07bln (exp. 1.06bln). FY20 Adj. EPS view 2.30-2.45 (exp. 2.45), FY20 revenue growth of 3-5%.
  • Franklin Resources (BEN) (Financials/Asset Management & Custody Banks) is to acquire its rival Legg Mason (LM) for USD 50/shr (Friday closing price: USD 40.72), in fitting with WSJ source reports this morning. BEN will assume USD 2bln of LM’s outstanding debt. The deal will see BEN as one of the largest independent, specialised global investment managers with a combined USD 1.5tln in AUM.
  • General Mills (GIS) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) reaffirmed its FY20 targets: Organic net sales +1-2%, constant-currency adjusted operating profit is expected +2-4%, constant-currency Adj. Diluted EPS +3-5%.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) announced it will be leaving Australia, New Zealand and Thailand to cut costs and move away from underperforming markets, which will cost roughly USD 1.1bln for the move.
  • Leidos Holdings Inc (LDOS) (Information Technology/IT Services) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 1.51 (exp. 1.35), Revenue 1.34 (exp. 2.84bln). FY EPS view 5.30-5.65 (exp. 5.52), FY20 Revenue view 12.6-13bln (exp. 12.02bln).
  • Medtronic plc (MDT) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) Q3 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 1.44 (exp. 1.38), Revenue 7.72bln (exp. 7.81bln). Q4 EPS view 1.62-1.64, raises FY 20 EPS guidance to 5.63-5.65 (Prev. 5.57-5.63).
  • Southwest Airlines (LUV) (Industrials/Airlines) machinists union announced it is looking for federal mediation to assist with contract talks following two years of negotiations.
  • United Technologies (UTX) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) EVP sold 12,546 common shares at USD 155.1841/shr.
  • Vulcan Materials (VMC) (Materials/Construction Materials) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 1.08 (exp. 1.17), Revenue 1.19bln (exp. 1.19bln). FY20 EPS view 5.20-5.80 (exp. 5.72), FY20 Adj. EBITDA between 1.385-1.485bln. Increased its quarterly dividend to USD 0.34/shr (prev. 0.31/shr)
  • Westinghouse Air Brake Technologies Corp (WAB) (Industrials/Machinery) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 1.04 (exp. 1.05), Revenue 2.37bln (exp. 2.19bln). FY20 EPS view 4.50-4.80 (exp. 4.76), FY Revenue view 8.7bln (exp. 8.56bln).
  • Xerox (XRX) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) reportedly is planning a dinner this week for HP Inc (HPQ) shareholders, with it being labelled as a “charm offensive” as XRX tries to takeover HPQ for USD 35bln.

OTHER

  • BHP (BHP AT/ BHP LN) (Materials/Metals & Mining) H1 (USD) adj. EBITDA 12.08bln (exp. 11.70bln, underlying profit 5.19bln (exp. 5.10bln). H1 interim dividend USD 0.63/shr, anticipates net demand loss in near term due to virus outbreak. Capital and exploration guidance remain unchanged.
  • Canopy Growth (CGC) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) CEO sated that one of the cost-cutting options is to cut jobs.
  • Dell Technology (DELL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) is reportedly near a deal to sell its cybersecurity unit to STG Partners for USD 2bln, according to WSJ.
  • Fluor (FLR) (Industrials/Construction & Engineering) announced the SEC is investigation the co. on past accounts and financial reports, and thus is to delay its results for Q4 19.
  • HSBC (5 HK/ HSBA LN) (Financials/Banks) FY (USD) Adj. pretax 22.2bln (exp. 21.77bln). Adj. revenue 55.41bln (prev. 53.9bln); cost reduction plan of USD 4.5bln; plans to suspend share buyback for 2020 and 2021 on expected restructuring. FY pre-tax profit (non-Adj) 13.347bln (prev. 19.890bln), FY CET1 ratio 14.7% (exp. 14.2%), FY NII USD 30.462bln (prev. 30.489bln) NIM 1.58% (prev. 1.66% YY). ROE 15.2% (prev. 16.0% YY). Q4 adj. pretax 4.3bln (exp. 3.9bln). Q4 interim dividend of USD 0.2/shr, envisages first 2020 interim dividend at USD 0.1/shr. Expects to incur restructuring costs of ~USD 6bln and asset disposal costs of ~USD 1.2bln during current period to 2022 - expects a majority of these costs to incur in 2020 and 2021. Co. will target a gross RWA reduction of USD 100bln by end-2022. Co. said its 2019 performance was resilient, however parts of business are not delivering. On the outlook, in long term, potentially sees lower revenue from lower lending transaction volumes due to coronavirus. Co. intends to reduce sales, trading and equity research in Europe. China, HK and UK continue to face challenges, also monitoring coronavirus. Lowered Asian economy growth forecasts. On restructuring, process for appointing a permanent group CEO is ongoing, expected within 6-12 months as initially outlined. Barry O'Byrne appointed as CEO of Global Commercial Banking. Charlie Nunn appointed as CEO of newly created Wealth and Personal Banking unit. Antonio Simoes to step down as CEO of Global Private Banking and will be leaving the Co.
  • Hyatt (H) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) increased its quarterly dividend to USD 0.20/shr (Prev. 0.19)
  • Mirati Therapeutics (MRTX) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced initial trial data for its Phase1/2 trial of sitravatinib in combination with nivolumab (BMY) for patients with advanced clear cell renal cell cancer. Found 15/38 patients achieved a confirmed partial response, and 35/38 achieved a clinical benefit.
  • Pacific Gas and Electric (PCG) (Utilities/Multi-Utilities) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.68 (exp. 0.67), remains on track to have its Chapter 11 plan confirmed by June 30th this year, announced it is filing a five year financial forecast that includes capital and rate base growth projections but it is not providing forecasts for FY20.
  • Pan Alto Networks (PANW) (Information Technology/Software) results are due on Feb. 24th, and Morgan Stanley analyst Keith Wess stated he would be long the company ahead of its report. His view is backed by checks continuing to show strong traction with Next-Gen cloud offering and a stable firewall business.

13-F FILINGS

Warren Buffet’s Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A/BRK.B)

  • Top Holdings: Apple (AAPL), Bank of America (BAC), Coca-Cola (KO), American Express (AXP), and Wells Fargo (WFC).
  • Added: Kroger (KR) and Biogen (BIIB)
  • Increased stake: Occidental (OXY), RH (RH), Suncor (SU), and General Motors (GM).
  • Reduced Stake: Wells Fargo (WFC), Goldman Sachs (GS), Travelers (TRV), Phillips 66 (PSX) and American Airlines (AAL), Apple (AAPL).
  • Exited: N/A

  • Top Holdings: Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Hilton Worldwide Holdings (HLT), Lowe's Companies (LOW), Restaurant Brands International (QSR), and Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B).
  • Added: N/A
  • Increased stake: Hughes (HHC) and Agilent Technologies (A).
  • Reduced Stake: Starbucks (SBUX).
  • Exited: N/A

David Tepper’s Appaloosa

  • Top Holdings: Alphabet Class C (GOOG), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Alibaba (BABA), and Micron (MU)
  • Added: Intelsat (I)
  • Increased stake: Alibaba (BABA), Micron (MU), Amazon (AMZN), Energy Transfer LP (ET), and UnitedHealth (UNH).
  • Reduced Stake: Clearway Energy Class C (CWEN), Clearway Energy Class A (CWEN.A), Caesars Entertainment (CZR), PG&E (PCG), and Broadcom (AVGO).
  • Exited: SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production ETF (XOP), Boeing (BA), and Mr Cooper Group (COOP).

George Soros’ Soros Fund Management

  • Top Holdings: Liberty Broadband (LBRDK), VICI Properties (VICI), Alphabet Class A (GOOGL), and Norton LifeLock (NLOK).
  • Added: Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Tiffany & Co. (TIF), Campbell Soup (CPB), and Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD).
  • Increased stake: NortonLifeLock (NLOK), Archer Daniels Midland (ADM), Vistra (VST), and Boeing (BA).

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 18th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are softer this morning in-line with the knock to risk-tone post AAPL revenue warning
  • Apple (AAPL) issued a revenue warning in which it does not expect to meet revenue guidance for the March quarter citing the coronavirus outbreak
  • China's President Xi says that China is still able to meet the 2020 economic targets, in-spite of the impact of the coronavirus
  • EZ Finance Minister, including German Finance Minister Scholz, have adopted a recommendation for a fiscal boost in the event of a downturn
  • Heavy Russian attacks on Ukraine in the Lugansk province have been reported
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US NY Fed Manufacturing, Japanese Trade Balance, ECB’s Panetta & Fed’s Kashkari

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China's Hubei province reports 1807 new coronavirus cases and 93 additional deaths as of February 17th vs. 1933 additional cases and 100 additional deaths on February 16th; Virus deal toll rises to 1800 vs. Prev. 1770. China reported an additional 1868 coronavirus cases and 98 additional deaths in the Mainland as of February 17, vs. 2048 additional cases and 105 deaths on February 16: Total Mainland cases at 72436 (Prev. 70548) and death toll at 1789 (Prev. 1770), while 1701 cured patients were discharged. China Global Times reported the number of patients infected with Coronavirus will likely peak during the second half of February in southern China; nationwide, the peak is seen in in April, according to the central government’s top medical advisor. (Newswires)

Apple (AAPL) issued a profit warning in which it does not expect to meet revenue guidance for the March quarter citing the coronavirus outbreak. Co. is experiencing a slower return to normal conditions than had anticipated and notes of slower demand in products in China alongside iPhone supply constraints. Co. said it will provide more information during its next earnings call in April and said the Co. is fundamentally strong and any disruptions to business is temporary. (Apple/Newswires) NOTE: Apple has an 11.64% weighting in NASDAQ 100, 7.5% in the DJIA, and 4.8% in S&P 500.

Tests for a coronavirus drug made by Gilead (GILD) are going slower than hoped amid struggles to recruit qualified patients, according to WSJ. (WSJ) Gilead's drug was seen as a promising remedy to tackle coronavirus. Elsewhere, Japanese Government Spokesman Suga said they soon aim to start trials using HIV treatment for coronavirus. (Newswires) Prior recent reports noted that HIV treatments have been showing positive signs against infected patients in China

US State Department official stated the incubation period for the coronavirus ranges from 2 to 14 days, with a median of 5-6 days. (Newswires) CDC has listed 467 people in 42 states in the US under investigation for the novel coronavirus. Of them, 15 have tested positive, 392 negative, and 60 are still pending, (CNN)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam said Hong Kong fund to tackle the virus outbreak has increased to HKD 28bln (Prev. HKD 25bln). (Newswires) South Korean President Moon called for 'special' economic policy measures to cope with 'emergency' situations caused by coronavirus, current economic situation is 'more serious' than thought, via Yonhap. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac equities traded with losses across the board following a non-existent lead from Wall Street, but as sentiment was dented following a profit warning by Apple, citing the coronavirus outbreak. At the electronic open, major US equity futures experienced downside, with Nasdaq Mar’20 futures immediately giving up the 9600 mark as Apple carries an 11%+ weighting in the index. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was led lower by broad losses across the majority of its stocks in the index, and with material names pressured amid a pullback in base metal prices and as mining-giant BHP traded lower despite topping Adj. EBITDA and underlying profit forecasts, as the miner anticipates net demand losses in the near term amid the virus outbreak. Nikkei 225 (-1.4%) conformed to the overall risk tone but underperformed the region throughout a bulk of the session amid currency dynamics, and with Nissan shares under renewed pressure after its CEO foresees challenges to earnings and cashflow for the remainder of the FY. Other notable movers from the Apple fallout included Samsung Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor, SK Hynix and Pegatron whose shares all traded lower by 1.5-3.0%. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.5%) and Shanghai Comp (U/C) joined the downbeat performance across the region, with the former weighed on by its heavyweight financials and oil-giants, whilst the latter fared slightly better following yesterday’s PBoC stimulus injection.

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9826vs. Exp. 6.9832 (Prev. 6.9795) (Newswires) PBoC drained a net CNY 220bln on the day

China's President Xi says that China is still able to meet the 2020 economic targets, in-spite of the impact of the coronavirus, State Media. (Newswires)

China said it is to receive applications for tariff exemptions for certain products from the US, as expected. Products include pork, beef and soybean - effective for one year. (Newswires)

US

Democratic Presidential Candidate Bloomberg has qualified for the Nevada debate this Wednesday after reaching 19% support in new NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll, according to a Bloomberg News journalist on Twitter. (Twitter)

-        The poll referenced in the Tweet is as follows: Sanders 31%, Bloomberg 19%, Biden 15%, Warren 12%, Klobuchar 9%, Buttigieg 8%, Steyer 2%

Top Trump administration officials are in discussions to reassign deputy national security adviser Victoria Coates to the Department of Energy from the National Security Council, according to sources cited by Axios. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK’s Chief Brexit Negotiator Frost said the central vision for the UK is to be able to set its own laws, to think that UK might accept EU supervision on level playing field is wrong and that the UK would not extend transition period beyond 2020, according to a draft. Frost added that tying UK to EU rules would undermine public backing for UK Government at home and UK expects open and fair competition based on FTA with EU. Frost also said the EU must endorse relationship of equals if it wants sustainable relationship with the UK. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson and Chancellor Sunak are reportedly mulling cutting the rate of pension tax relief for higher earnings to 20% from 40%, which could raise GBP 10bln per annum, according to the Times. (Times) This also follows recent reports that Sunak is considering abandoning current fiscal rules that control day-to-day spending and ensure the government aims to reduce debt levels. Subsequently, Sunak has confirmed the budget will occur on March 11th. (Newswires)

Number 10 Adviser Andrew Sabisky has resigned after a string of controversial posts were uncovered. (Sky News)

EZ Finance Minister, including German Finance Minister Scholz, have adopted a recommendation for a fiscal boost in the event of a downturn. (Newswires)

UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Dec) 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.8%); Employment Change (Dec) 180k vs. Exp. 145k (Prev. 208k).

-        Avg Wk Earnings 3M YY (Dec) 2.9% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 3.2%); (Ex-Bonus) (Dec) 3.2% vs. Exp. 3.3% (Prev. 3.4%)

-        Claimant Count Unem Chng (Jan) 5.5k (Prev. 14.9k, Rev. 2.6k)

German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Feb) 8.7 vs. Exp. 21.5 (Prev. 26.7); Current Conditions (Feb) -15.7 vs. Exp. -10.3 (Prev. -9.5)

GEOPOLITICS 

Heavy Russian attack on the Ukrainian front in the Lugansk province, heavy weapons have been used with deaths reported on both sides. Attack has been occurring for over 4-hours, Ukrainian reinforcements reportedly on the way, Bild's Ropcke. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities (Eurostoxx 50 -0.4%) mostly reside in negative territory as the fallout from Apple’s (pre-market -3.3%), revenue warning reverberates across the marketplace. Apple ‘s warning for Q1 revenue guidance was attributed to the coronavirus with the Co. noting it is experiencing a slower return to normal conditions than had anticipated and noted slower demand in products in China alongside iPhone supply constraints. Given that rival peers will likely be subject to similar supply-chain disruptions, IT names lag this morning with ASML International (-2.0%), Dialog Semiconductor (-4.5%), STMicroelectronics (-3%) and Infineon (-1.5%) all enduring losses. From a more medium-term perspective (referring to the US semiconductor sector), Credit Suisse notes “while we expect Semis to trade lower - we would recommend investors who can look into 2H and beyond should use weakness to accumulate best in class companies with a solid structural outlook”. Elsewhere, given the broader macro implications of Apple’s warning, material names are also softer thus far with uninspiring updates from Glencore (-3.9%) and BHP (-2.6%) pressuring the sector. Financials are falling victim to lower yields and a lacklustre update from HSBC (-5.7%) with the Co. unveiling a 33% decline in profits and a restructuring plan that will lead to a job cull of around 35k. Bucking the trend of the pessimism in Europe is the FTSE MIB (+0.3%), in the wake of Intesa Sanpaolo’s (+2.0%) takeover approach for UBI Banca (+22%), which has also stoked optimism around the prospect of further sector consolidation in Italy.

Apple (AAPL) - Co. does not expect to meet revenue guidance for March quarter citing coronavirus, Co. is experiencing a slower return to normal conditions than had anticipated; notes slower demand in products in China alongside iPhone supply constraints. Citing: worldwide iPhone supply will be temporarily constrained, demand for our products within China has been affected. "The situation is evolving, and we will provide more information during our next earnings call in April." & "Apple is fundamentally strong, and this disruption to our business is only temporary.". (Newswires) Co. are 3.3% lower in pre-market

Walmart Inc (WMT) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 1.38 (exp. 1.44), Revenue 141.7bln (exp. 142.52bln); US Q4 comp sales +1.9% vs. Exp. +2.4%. Net sales USD 140.61bln vs. Prev. USD 137.74bln, Sees FY EPS USD 5.00-5.15, vs. Exp. USD 5.22, Quarterly GAAP & adj. EPS lowered by circa USD 0.05 due to disruptions in Chile as well as a legal matter affecting Sam's Club. (Newswires) Co. have a 2.7% weighting in the DJIA

FX

USD/JPY/CHF/XAU - Although daily updates from China continue to signal that the worst may be over in terms of coronavirus cases and casualties, Apple has joined others issuing warnings about the fallout hitting Q1 production and sales targets with wider repercussions for the tech sector and risk sentiment in general. Hence, the traditional safe haven currencies (and assets) have regained a firm bid after losing some appeal at the start of the week and the DXY is back on track to post higher 2020 peaks as it edges further above 99.000 with only the likes of the Yen, Franc and Gold managing to keep pace or stay ahead of the Greenback. Indeed, Usd/Jpy has eased back a bit further from recent 110.00+ levels, while Usd/Chf is gravitating back towards 0.9800 alongside Eur/Chf on the 1.0600 handle and Usd/Xau is just below Usd1590/oz compared to a low of Usd1579 yesterday. Back to the index, 99.249 resistance has been eclipsed and 99.500 is the obvious next target for bulls ahead of last year’s 99.667 best.

NZD/AUD/SEK/NOK - The Antipodes are vying with their Scandi peers for the unenviable, though largely unavoidable tag of biggest G10 lower, and the Kiwi is shading it as Nzd/Usd slips under 0.6400 and Aud/Nzd holds near 1.0450 even though Aud/Usd has lost grip of the 0.6700 handle in wake of RBA minutes also flagging the Chinese nCoV outbreak as the biggest near term threat and keeping a rate cut on the table. Meanwhile, the Swedish Crown has been undermined by a rebound in jobless rates and its Norwegian counterpart by a sharp retreat in crude prices amidst the broad deterioration in risk appetite, with Eur/Sek up over 10.5600 at one stage and Eur/Nok near the top of a 10.0220-10.1100 range.

GBP - Bucking the overall trend, and seemingly gleaning a belated fillip from encouraging UK jobs data (claimant count and employment change) Cable has recouped all and more of its losses around 1.3000 after testing major technical support at 1.2971 (where the 10 DMA aligns with a 50% Fib retracement), while Eur/Gbp has reversed from circa 0.8350 to just above 0.8300. Note, some selling subsequently noted in the headline pair around the 200 WMA (1.3038).

EUR/CAD - Both succumbing to widespread Usd strength, with the single currency also weighing up divergent independent factors in the form of a worrying ZEW survey in contrast to reports that all Eurogroup Finance Ministers are on board with apportioning some budget finances in the event of an economic downturn, whatever that is deemed to be in terms of severity and how much cash will be allocated. Eur/Usd skirting last week’s 1.0821 base vs around 1.0837 at one stage, while Usd/Cad straddles 1.3250 ahead of Canadian manufacturing sales and with the Loonie also hampered by the aforementioned recoil in oil.

EM - Further depreciation vs the Dollar across the board, but the Rand also wary about more Eskom load-shedding, while the Lira and Rouble are still embroiled in Syria-related issues, and the latter also undermined by heightened conflict in the Ukraine.

RBA Minutes (Feb) reiterated that the Board discussed the case for further easing, chose to hold given that rates are already low and repeated that the Board remained prepared to ease further if needed. The minutes also highlighted that Coronavirus is a “material” risk to the Chinese economy and hence Australia, whilst reiterating that there was uncertainty around estimates of the effects of the bushfires and the coronavirus outbreak and it’s too early to judge virus impact. The release noted that economic drag from bushfires to be felt in Q4 and Q1, full recovery expected by year-end and it’s reasonable to expect that an extended period of low-interest rates would be required in Australia to reach full employment and achieve the inflation target. Finally, the minutes repeated that the outlook remained for the Australian economy to improve due in part to housing pick-up. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Core debt has pared gains across the board, partly in recognition of an inverse bounce in equities from worst levels, but also as Bunds digest news that Eurozone Governments are willing to loosen fiscal policy if economic developments worsen and Schatz digest a decent if not downright solid Eur5 bn auction. The 10 year EU benchmarks are all off peaks that came in at 174.92, 133.87 and 131-12+ on Eurex, Liffe and overnight UST trade respectively, albeit still holding up relatively well ahead of the return of Treasury cash markets after Presidents’ Day and eyeing the Empire State survey before NAHB and a late speech from Fed’s Kashkari for further inspiration.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front month futures are subdued this morning with losses just shy of USD 1/bbl at present in-line with the general risk sentiment. Newsflow has picked up on the geopolitical front, although not enough to dictate price action at present; with focus returning to the ongoing dispute between Russia and Ukraine which has flamed up once more on reports of heavy fighting in the Lugansk province. Ukraine has one of the largest gas transmission systems in the world, which is heavily linked to Russian, Belarus, Poland and other surrounding nations; the region in question does contain a number of gas pipelines but it is unclear as to whether they are currently in use as a bypass has been constructed. Focus will remain on how this escalates, and if it leads to disruptions to gas supply. Sticking with Russia, the Kremlin this morning noted that Energy Minister Novak is still considering his position with reference to the recommended JTC production cuts. In terms of outlook, given the coronavirus ING have revised down their price forecasts as the virus causes consumption to drop; with cuts of USD 5/bbl for Q1 Brent (from USD 60/bbl to USD 55/bbl), although their forecasts are unchanged by 2021. Note, given the US holiday the weekly API and EIA metrics will be released one day late on Wednesday and Thursday respectfully. Turning to metals, where spot gold is firmer this morning on the aforementioned geo-political tensions and as the coronavirus begins to impact US tech giants; albeit, the metal has dipped marginally from session highs in recent trade ahead of the US’ entrance to market. Elsewhere, copper prices are little changed but were hit overnight in-line with general risk sentiment.

Libya’s NOC said its oil production stood at 135,745 BPD on Monday 17th vs. 163,684 on Thursday 13th. (Newswires)

China Trade Body said some customers in Russia, Turkey, Middle East and North Africa have stopped accepting China metals products deliveries amid the virus outbreak. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities (Eurostoxx 50 -0.4%) mostly reside in negative territory as the fallout from Apple’s (German listing -4%), revenue warning reverberates across the marketplace. Apple ‘s warning for Q1 revenue guidance was attributed to the coronavirus with the Co. noting it is experiencing a slower return to normal conditions than had anticipated and noted slower demand in products in China alongside iPhone supply constraints. Given that rival peers will likely be subject to similar supply-chain disruptions, IT names lag this morning with ASML International (-2.0%), Dialog Semiconductor (-4.5%), STMicroelectronics (-3%) and Infineon (-1.5%) all enduring losses. From a more medium-term perspective (referring to the US semiconductor sector), Credit Suisse notes “while we expect Semis to trade lower - we would recommend investors who can look into 2H and beyond should use weakness to accumulate best in class companies with a solid structural outlook”. Elsewhere, given the broader macro implications of Apple’s warning, material names are also softer thus far with uninspiring updates from Glencore (-3.9%) and BHP (-2.6%) pressuring the sector. Financials are falling victim to lower yields and a lacklustre update from HSBC (-5.7%) with the Co. unveiling a 33% decline in profits and a restructuring plan that will lead to a job cull of around 35k. Bucking the trend of the pessimism in Europe is the FTSE MIB (+0.3%), in the wake of Intesa Sanpaolo’s (+2.0%) takeover approach for UBI Banca (+22%), which has also stoked optimism around the prospect of further sector consolidation in Italy.

FX

USD/JPY/CHF/XAU - Although daily updates from China continue to signal that the worst may be over in terms of coronavirus cases and casualties, Apple has joined others issuing warnings about the fallout hitting Q1 production and sales targets with wider repercussions for the tech sector and risk sentiment in general. Hence, the traditional safe haven currencies (and assets) have regained a firm bid after losing some appeal at the start of the week and the DXY is back on track to post higher 2020 peaks as it edges further above 99.000 with only the likes of the Yen, Franc and Gold managing to keep pace or stay ahead of the Greenback. Indeed, Usd/Jpy has eased back a bit further from recent 110.00+ levels, while Usd/Chf is gravitating back towards 0.9800 alongside Eur/Chf on the 1.0600 handle and Usd/Xau is just below Usd1590/oz compared to a low of Usd1579 yesterday. Back to the index, 99.249 resistance has been eclipsed and 99.500 is the obvious next target for bulls ahead of last year’s 99.667 best.

NZD/AUD/SEK/NOK - The Antipodes are vying with their Scandi peers for the unenviable, though largely unavoidable tag of biggest G10 lower, and the Kiwi is shading it as Nzd/Usd slips under 0.6400 and Aud/Nzd holds near 1.0450 even though Aud/Usd has lost grip of the 0.6700 handle in wake of RBA minutes also flagging the Chinese nCoV outbreak as the biggest near term threat and keeping a rate cut on the table. Meanwhile, the Swedish Crown has been undermined by a rebound in jobless rates and its Norwegian counterpart by a sharp retreat in crude prices amidst the broad deterioration in risk appetite, with Eur/Sek up over 10.5600 at one stage and Eur/Nok near the top of a 10.0220-10.1100 range.

GBP - Bucking the overall trend, and seemingly gleaning a belated fillip from encouraging UK jobs data (claimant count and employment change) Cable has recouped all and more of its losses around 1.3000 after testing major technical support at 1.2971 (where the 10 DMA aligns with a 50% Fib retracement), while Eur/Gbp has reversed from circa 0.8350 to just above 0.8300. Note, some selling subsequently noted in the headline pair around the 200 WMA (1.3038).

EUR/CAD - Both succumbing to widespread Usd strength, with the single currency also weighing up divergent independent factors in the form of a worrying ZEW survey in contrast to reports that all Eurogroup Finance Ministers are on board with apportioning some budget finances in the event of an economic downturn, whatever that is deemed to be in terms of severity and how much cash will be allocated. Eur/Usd skirting last week’s 1.0821 base vs around 1.0837 at one stage, while Usd/Cad straddles 1.3250 ahead of Canadian manufacturing sales and with the Loonie also hampered by the aforementioned recoil in oil.

EM - Further depreciation vs the Dollar across the board, but the Rand also wary about more Eskom load-shedding, while the Lira and Rouble are still embroiled in Syria-related issues, and the latter also undermined by heightened conflict in the Ukraine.

FIXED INCOME

Core debt has pared gains across the board, partly in recognition of an inverse bounce in equities from worst levels, but also as Bunds digest news that Eurozone Governments are willing to loosen fiscal policy if economic developments worsen and Schatz digest a decent if not downright solid Eur5 bn auction. The 10 year EU benchmarks are all off peaks that came in at 174.92, 133.87 and 131-12+ on Eurex, Liffe and overnight UST trade respectively, albeit still holding up relatively well ahead of the return of Treasury cash markets after Presidents’ Day and eyeing the Empire State survey before NAHB and a late speech from Fed’s Kashkari for further inspiration.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front month futures are subdued this morning with losses just shy of USD 1/bbl at present in-line with the general risk sentiment. Newsflow has picked up on the geopolitical front, although not enough to dictate price action at present; with focus returning to the ongoing dispute between Russia and Ukraine which has flamed up once more on reports of heavy fighting in the Lugansk province. Ukraine has one of the largest gas transmission systems in the world, which is heavily linked to Russian, Belarus, Poland and other surrounding nations; the region in question does contain a number of gas pipelines but it is unclear as to whether they are currently in use as a bypass has been constructed. Focus will remain on how this escalates, and if it leads to disruptions to gas supply. Sticking with Russia, the Kremlin this morning noted that Energy Minister Novak is still considering his position with reference to the recommended JTC production cuts. In terms of outlook, given the coronavirus ING have revised down their price forecasts as the virus causes consumption to drop; with cuts of USD 5/bbl for Q1 Brent (from USD 60/bbl to USD 55/bbl), although their forecasts are unchanged by 2021. Note, given the US holiday the weekly API and EIA metrics will be released one day late on Wednesday and Thursday respectfully. Turning to metals, where spot gold is firmer this morning on the aforementioned geo-political tensions and as the coronavirus begins to impact US tech giants; albeit, the metal has dipped marginally from session highs in recent trade ahead of the US’ entrance to market. Elsewhere, copper prices are little changed but were hit overnight in-line with general risk sentiment.

subject: UK debt and STIR contracts continue comeback pre-employment and earnings data
content: Gilts and Short Sterling futures are off best levels as the FTSE gleans some underlying traction from another bout of broad Pound weakness, but the 10 year debt benchmark and 3 month strip have clawed back more lost ground from recent lows on the back of renewed China nCoV angst manifest in corporate guidance warnings and downbeat economic assessments from Asian countries close to the outbreak. Looking at early Liffe price action, Gilts were marked up at 133.83 initially vs yesterday’s 133.46 close and only advanced a further 2 ticks before running into offers just ahead of resistance at 133.88 (February 14 high) and STIRs are now 1-1.5 ticks firmer having been 2.5 ticks above par at one stage. Ahead, jobs and wage data kick off a run of primary macro reports through to the end of the week.

Bunds: firmer rebound from Monday’s lows and through near term resistance
content: The risk pendulum has swung around yet again, away from global stocks and similar assets amidst a spate of warnings about the fallout from China’s coronavirus, and chiefly from tech heavyweight Apple, but also via HSBC and South East Asian nations including South Korea and Singapore. Accordingly, safe-havens have regained a strong bid and sufficient to lift the core Eurozone bond up and beyond upside chart hurdles that have been capping recovery rallies of late, at 174.69 and now 174.89, leaving little in the way of a return to the 175.00 psychological and then early February peaks just above the big figure. Bunds are currently just a tick or so below 174.92, and a bleak ZEW survey could provide bulls with more impetus, assuming EU cash bourses do not collapse to spark an even more pronounced FTQ in the meantime.

Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

18th February 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia-Pac equities traded with losses across the board following a non-existent lead from Wall Street, but as sentiment was dented following a profit warning by Apple, citing the coronavirus outbreak. At the electronic open, major US equity futures experienced downside, with Nasdaq Mar’20 futures immediately giving up the 9600 mark as Apple carries an 11%+ weighting in the index. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was led lower by broad losses across the majority of its stocks in the index, and with material names pressured amid a pullback in base metal prices and as mining-giant BHP traded lower despite topping Adj. EBITDA and underlying profit forecasts, as the miner anticipates net demand losses in the near term amid the virus outbreak. Nikkei 225 (-1.4%) conformed to the overall risk tone but underperformed the region throughout a bulk of the session amid currency dynamics, and with Nissan shares under renewed pressure after its CEO foresees challenges to earnings and cashflow for the remainder of the FY. Other notable movers from the Apple fallout included Samsung Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor, SK Hynix and Pegatron whose shares all traded lower by 1.5-3.0%. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.5%) and Shanghai Comp (-0.4%) joined the downbeat performance across the region, with the former weighed on by its heavyweight financials and oil-giants, whilst the latter fared slightly better following yesterday’s PBoC stimulus injection.

FTSE 100

BHP (BHP LN) – H1 adj. EBITDA USD 12.08bln vs. Exp. USD 11.70bln, underlying profit USD 5.19bln vs. Exp. USD 5.10bln. H1 interim dividend USD 0.63/shr, anticipates net demand loss in near term due to virus outbreak; capital & exploration guidance is unchanged. CEO notes that production demand remains resilient. (Newswires)

BT (BT/A LN) – Co. are to stop their pay-TV packages and instead implement a monthly payment system where customers can pay for the content they want. (Guardian)

HSBC (HSBA LN) – FY Adj. pretax USD 22.2bln vs. Exp. USD 21.77bln. Adj. revenue USD 55.41bln vs. Prev. USD 53.9bln; cost reduction plan of USD 4.5bln; plans to suspend share buyback for 2020 and 2021 on expected restructuring. FY pre-tax profit (non-Adj) USD 13.347bln vs. Prev. USD 19.890bln, CET1 ratio 14.7% vs. Exp. 14.2%, NII USD 30.462bln vs. Prev. USD 30.489bln, NIM 1.58% vs. Prev. 1.66% YY, ROE 15.2% vs. Prev. 16.0% YY. Q4 results: adj. pretax USD 4.3bln vs. Exp. USD 3.9bln, interim dividend of USD 0.2/shr, envisages first 2020 interim dividend at USD 0.1/shr. Expects to incur restructuring costs of ~USD 6bln and asset disposal costs of ~USD 1.2bln during current period to 2022 - expects a majority of these costs to incur in 2020 and 2021; notes 2019 performance was resilient but some sections are not delivering. On the restructuring: process for appointing a permanent group CEO is ongoing, expected within 6-12 months as initially outlined, the strategy means circa 35k in job cuts over the next 3-years. Looking ahead: potentially sees lower long-term revenue from lower lending transaction volumes due to coronavirus, separately they intend to reduce sales, trading and equity research in Europe. (Newswires) Co. have a 7% FTSE 100 weighting and are circa 2.3% lower in APAC trade.

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN) – FDA has approved the Co’s Voltaren arthritis pain-relief for over the counter usage in the US. (Newswires)

RBS (RBS LN) - Charles Donald is set to take over as CEO of UK Government Investments as of March 12th. Donald is currently the head of the financial institutions group at UKGI, where he has been overseeing the RBS stake and as such, some have suggested that his promotion could heighten the prospect of the government further reducing its 62% stake in the Co. (Times)
